text: my name is leah vader and i'm a
solutions architect at aws
seven and a half years ago i started in
aws premium support but
once i got there i realized i had a lot
of different interests and so i learned
about the solutions architect role i
talked to my manager and he helped me
move and that's actually where i've been
since but i've been in different
solutions architect type roles like my
first role i was working with startups
and then i moved on to our larger
enterprise customers and then i moved on
to a couple specialization roles
serverless and then now developer
acceleration
and really all that is because every
time i see something new and interesting
i talk to my manager and i tell them my
interest and they help me make that move
whatever steps it takes whether it be
working with other teams whether it be
shadowing opportunities our managers are
really empowered to help us build our
careers
my current role is a little bit
different than any other solutions
architect role that i've had before
because i wrote the narrative for this
team and it became a team and now i get
to to work on that team and help build
out something completely new so what
this means is we have a writing culture
so we write something called narratives
and we write out what our plan is how we
execute how this benefits our customers
and this is how a lot of our teams and
products even have started
when i first started there are very few
women in solutions architecture and we
started our own slack channel and there
was about 10 of us in it but over time
we've actually hired a lot more women
and it's a very large group now
my advice to women who are wanting to
get into tech is just dive in and try
out really anything like go try out some
programming classes and there's lots of
free ones online go log into aws console
and use the free tier try a bunch of new
things and then figure out what you
really like and what's interesting to
you and then focus in on that
